title: Organic farming - WELS (Waterpedia Environmental Learning Series)

tasks.task: Understand the concepts and practices of organic farming compared to conventional farming.
subtasks: Recognize the growth in human population and its impact on farming practices.
Identify the sustainable population limits according to some scientists.
Comprehend the intensification of farming to meet food demands.
Analyze the role of fertilizers, pesticides, and animal husbandry practices in conventional farming.
Learn about the global percentage of organic farming and its focus on sustainability.
Explore the environmental benefits of organic farming over conventional methods.
Understand the limitations of organic farming in terms of yield and biodiversity.
Compare the use of natural alternatives like manure and crop rotation in organic farming.
Recognize the labor-intensive nature of organic farming practices like manual weeding.
Discuss the potential for organic farming to maintain biodiversity and produce healthier products.

tasks.task: Examine the problems and realities of organic farming.
subtasks: Research the common issues faced by organic farms beyond theoretical benefits.
Understand the challenges in transitioning from conventional to organic farming methods.
Analyze the economic aspects of organic farming and product pricing.
Consider the trade-offs between environmental benefits and lower yields in organic farming.

tasks.task: Consider the implications of organic farming for addressing climate change.
Reflect on the future of farming and the role of organic versus conventional methods.
